carrots tossed in butter

definitions.meaning: If you toss your hair or a part of your body you move it up and back suddenly
examples: She tossed her head in annoyance.
She tossed back her hair.

definitions.meaning: to move about from side to side or turn a lot in bed, especially because you cannot sleep
examples: I was tossing and turning all night.

definitions.meaning: to throw a coin up into the air and guess which side will land facing up, as a way of making a decision
examples: Let's toss (a coin) to see who'll go first.
"I'll toss you for it - heads or tails?"
Let's toss a coin to see who'll go first.
He tossed the letter into the bin.
They tossed the beggars a few coins.
I tossed a few clothes into a suitcase.
I tossed a clove of garlic into the stew.

definitions.meaning: an important positive development
examples: The West made impressive strides in improving energy efficiency after the huge rises in oil prices during the 70s.
The group has made strides to expand internationally.

definitions.meaning: a long step when walking or running
examples: She attributes her record-breaking speed to the length of her stride.

definitions.meaning: trousers
examples: a new pair of strides

definitions.meaning: to walk somewhere quickly with long steps
examples: She strode purposefully up to the desk and demanded to speak to the manager.
He strode across/into/out of the room.

definitions.meaning: not completely trusting or certain about something or someone
examples: I'm a little wary of/about giving people my address when I don't know them very well.
All authors need to be wary of inadvertent copying of other people's ideas.
The legal system is full of snares for those who are not wary.
Tourists should be wary, as pickpockets are known to operate in this area.
Buyers should be wary of hidden costs when purchasing their holiday.
The teacher was wary of giving his pupils too much information at once.

definitions.meaning: to express a thought, feeling, or idea so that it is understood by other people
examples: His poetry conveys a great sense of religious devotion.
Please convey our condolences to the family.
I tried to convey in my speech how grateful we all were for his help.
You don't want to convey the impression that we're not interested.

definitions.meaning: to take or carry someone or something to a particular place
examples: The goods are usually conveyed by rail.
Could you convey a message to Mr Merrick for me, please?
Few journalists have managed to convey the full horror of the situation.
What the book does convey very successfully is the horror of war.
No report can convey the unspeakable suffering that this war has caused.
Words alone cannot convey the untold misery endured by people in these refugee camps.
With a single wag of her finger she managed to convey her total disapproval.

definitions.meaning: to criticize something or someone strongly, usually for moral reasons
examples: The terrorist action has been condemned as an act of barbarism and cowardice.
The film was condemned for its sexism.
She was the only politician to condemn the proposed law on moral grounds .
The president took the unusual step of altering his prepared speech in order to condemn the terrorist attack.
Her refusal to condemn the violence left her open to the charge of positive support for the campaign .
Prince Charles condemned the assertively modernist style of architecture.
The Opposition has condemned the government's proposed tax increases.

definitions.meaning: to get better after an illness, or feel better after something or someone has made you unhappy
examples: She was only just getting over the flu when she got a stomach bug.
It took him years to get over the shock of his wife dying.
It took her months to get over Michael when he ended the relationship.
She's only just getting over the death of her husband.
He is still getting over the shock of being made redundant.
It will take him a long time to get over the operation.
You will get over the illness more quickly if you relax.
She never completely got over the loss of her first child.

definitions.meaning: to do something that you have intended to do for a long time
examples: I still haven't got around to fixing that tap.
I intended to tidy the flat at the weekend, but I didn't get round to it.
It's been at the back of my mind to call José for several days now, but I haven't got round to it yet.
He never did get around to putting up the shelves.
After weeks of putting it off, she finally got around to painting the bedroom.
Did you get round to doing the shopping?

definitions.meaning: to finally agree to what someone wants, after refusing for a period of time
examples: He nagged me so much for a new bike that eventually I gave in.
The government cannot be seen as giving in to terrorists' demands.

definitions.meaning: to accept that you have been defeated and agree to stop competing or fighting
examples: You'll never guess the answer - do you give in?
She wouldn't give in until she received a full apology.
After a heated debate, the employers gave in to the union's demands.
I don't think he will give in to your requests if you keep pestering him.
He gave in to my suggestion after I had shown him the plans.
Keep asking and eventually she'll give in.
The government finally gave in to the company's plea for help.
He held the other wrestler in a headlock until he gave in.
The enemy troops weren't prepared to give in without a fight.
After struggling with the crossword for an hour, she finally gave in and looked at the answers.
She refused to give in, and finally got the opportunity she was looking for.
If your application is rejected this year, don't give in. You can apply again next year.

definitions.meaning: nervous and worried and unable to relax
examples: She was very tense as she waited for the interview.

definitions.meaning: If a situation is tense, it causes feelings of worry or nervousness
examples: There were some tense moments in the second half of the game.
This attack will exacerbate the already tense relations between the two communities.
The weeks following the riots were extremely tense.
For a few tense minutes, the astronauts lost radio contact with mission control.
Hendry won the world snooker title after a tense 35-frame final.

definitions.meaning: If you or your muscles tense, your muscles become stiff and tight because you are frightened or nervous, or are preparing yourself to do something
examples: Don't tense your shoulders, just relax.
I could feel myself tense up as he touched my neck.

definitions.meaning: very nervous and worried and unable to relax because of something that is going to happen
examples: You seem all tensed up. Are you still waiting for that call?

definitions.meaning: lasting forever or for a very long time
examples: The company is engaged in the eternal search for a product that will lead the market.
Will you two never stop your eternal arguing!

definitions.meaning: to explain something or make something clear
examples: I don't understand. You'll have to elucidate.
The reasons for the change in weather conditions have been elucidated by several scientists.

definitions.meaning: to spend time considering a possible future action, or to consider one particular thing for a long time in a serious and quiet way
examples: I'm contemplating going abroad for a year.
They were contemplating a move to California.
It's too awful/horrific/dangerous to contemplate.
I'm contemplating leaving my job.
Losing a child is just too awful to contemplate.
I couldn't contemplate living on my own.
He was contemplating his future.

definitions.meaning: something that encourages a person to do something
examples: Tax incentives have been very effective in encouraging people to save and invest more of their income.
There is little incentive for people to leave their cars at home when public transport remains so expensive.
Bonus payments provide an incentive to work harder.
Indexation of pay rises to productivity will give people an incentive to work harder.
The incentive to sell more is large - and it plainly works.
The management have introduced a productivity incentive scheme for members of staff.
Tax incentives have been offered to attract industry to the region.
The new law provides incentives for businesses to invest in recycling equipment.

definitions.meaning: to examine or look at something in a careful or detailed way
examples: Remember to go over your essay to check for grammar and spelling mistakes.

definitions.meaning: to study or explain something again
examples: Let’s go over the rules once more before we begin.

definitions.meaning: used to tell someone they have done well, or used humorously when someone has done something stupid:
examples: I heard you girls won the contest. Way to go!
Way to go, John - you broke the chair!

definitions.meaning: to press or be pressed against something with a circular or up-and-down repeated movement
examples: She yawned and rubbed her eyes sleepily.
He rubbed (at) the stain on his trousers and made it worse.
We rubbed some polish into the surface of the wood.
She gently rubbed the ointment in.
First rub the baking tray well with butter.
Alice rubbed the blackboard clean for the teacher.
Your cat keeps on rubbing itself (up) against my leg.
She was rubbing her hands (together) at the thought of winning.
The branches rubbed against each other in the wind.
The chair legs have rubbed holes in the carpet.
My new shoes are rubbing (against/on my toe) and now I've got blisters.
These marks will never rub off (= be cleaned off).
Alice rubbed the sums off (= cleaned them off) the blackboard for the teacher.
She rubbed sun lotion over her entire body.
With the back of his hand, he rubbed the stubble on his chin.
He rubbed his hand despairingly over his face.
The strap had rubbed against his skin and caused irritation.
The shoe had rubbed a raw place on her heel.

definitions.meaning: the act of rubbing something
examples: He gave her hair a good rub to dry it.

definitions.meaning: a cover fixed over a seat or bed, etc. for shelter or decoration
the branches and leaves that spread out at the top of a group of trees forming a type of roof
the transparent part in a military aircraft that covers the place where the pilot sits
the large circular piece of cloth that is the main part of a parachute
extremely expensive
examples: The price of books nowadays is extortionate.

definitions.meaning: to pull or be pulled apart, or to pull pieces off
examples: You have to be very careful with books this old because the paper tears very easily.
I tore my skirt on the chair as I stood up.
A couple of pages had been torn out of/from the book.

definitions.meaning: to move very quickly
examples: He went tearing along the road after the bus.
She tried to tear a small piece off the edge.
I tore off a piece of paper.
The dog's claws tore her dress.
The sheet tore right down the middle.
You need to tear off the top of the packet.

definitions.meaning: (of fruit or crops) completely developed and ready to be collected or eaten
examples: Those bananas aren't ripe yet - they're still green.
The pods split open when the beans are ripe.
The oil is made by crushing and pressing ripe olives.
Ripe figs spoil easily and cannot be shipped long distances.
The fruit turns red when it is ripe.
The fruit is picked before it turns ripe.

definitions.meaning: a deep, round pan with straight sides, usually with a handle and a lid, used for cooking things over heat

examples: an aluminium saucepan
Put a lid on the saucepan.
Empty the soup into a saucepan and simmer gently for ten minutes.
He scrubbed the old saucepan clean and it looked as good as new.
That saucepan is going to boil over.

definitions.meaning: an aircraft with a jet engine that is able to fly very fast
examples: a jet plane
a private jet
We flew to New York by jet.

definitions.meaning: a thin stream of something, such as water or gas, that is forced out of a small hole
examples: She turned on the hose and a jet of water sprayed across the yard.

definitions.meaning: a small hole in a piece of equipment through which gas or another fuel is forced before it is burned
examples: I think the gas jet must be blocked, because the oven won't light.

definitions.meaning: a hard, black stone that shines when it is rubbed and is used to make jewellery and other decorative objects

examples: The jet crash-landed and burst into flames.
The jet levelled off at 10,000 feet.
The private jet is a symbol of wealth.
Moments before crashing, the jet was seen veering sharply to the right.
Most of the planes that carry passengers across the Atlantic are wide-bodied jets.

definitions.meaning: relating to experience, real situations, or actions rather than ideas or imagination
examples: Qualifications are important but practical experience is always an plus.
The service offers young people practical advice on finding a job.
What's the use of theoretical knowledge that has no practical application?

definitions.meaning: suitable for the situation in which something is used
examples: I tend to wear clothes that are practical rather than fashionable.
Heavy boots aren't very practical for running.

definitions.meaning: able to provide effective solutions to problems
examples: She has lots of interesting ideas, but they're not very practical.
We need someone practical who can cope with a crisis.
It's all very well knowing things in theory but what you need to gain is practical experience.
So how does this theory translate into practical policy?
Greater emphasis is given to practical tests rather than written work.
We offer practical help for people with disabilities.
There are various practical problems that we need to overcome.

definitions.meaning: to give something to each person in a group or place
examples: The teacher asked her to hand out the worksheets.
They stood on the street corner handing out leaflets.
Demonstrators handed out leaflets to passers-by.
While the teacher was talking, her assistant handed out pens and paper for us all.
Before you leave, I have some notices to hand out to you all.
Sam's mum handed out sweets, birthday cake and balloons to everyone at the end of the party.
Could you hand out the books for me, David? One to everyone, please.

definitions.meaning: to tell a secret or show your feelings unintentionally
examples: I'm not giving away any plot surprises; read the review in the paper if you want to know them.
The look on her face gave her away (= showed her real feelings).

definitions.meaning: to supply something at no charge
examples: They’re giving away shopping bags.

definitions.meaning: to cause worry to someone
examples: The state of my father's health concerns us greatly.
It concerns me that he hasn't been in contact.

definitions.meaning: to be important to someone or to involve someone directly
examples: Matters of pollution and the environment concern us all.
What I have to say to Amy doesn't concern you.

definitions.meaning: If a story, film, or article concerns a particular subject, person, etc., it is about that person or subject
examples: The documentary concerns a woman who goes to China as a missionary.

definitions.meaning: to become involved with something, or worried about something
examples: There's no need for you to concern yourself with what happened.
Don't concern yourself. She'll be home soon.

definitions.meaning: something you write at the start of a formal letter or notice when you do not know exactly who it should be sent to

examples: We're now going to turn to an issue that concerns us all - racism.
His attitude concerns me.
The poor state of the fire escapes concerned me greatly.
It concerned them that no doctor was available.
Does it concern you that your children are out after dark?
Trigonometry concerns the functions of angles, such as sine, cosine and tangent.
How I choose to vote does not concern you.
The documentary concerns the eating habits of Britain's teenagers.
I didn't go to the meeting because nothing on the agenda seemed to concern me.
I'll answer any questions that specifically concern this week's homework.

definitions.meaning: a worried or nervous feeling about something, or something that makes you feel worried
examples: Concern for the safety of the two missing teenagers is growing.
There's a lot of public concern about/over dangerous toxins recently found in food.
My concern is that you're not getting enough work done.

definitions.meaning: a company
examples: a family concern
It started slowly, but the company is now a going concern (= doing business effectively).

definitions.meaning: something that is important to you, or the fact of being important
examples: His concern to appear sophisticated amused everyone.
The company's sole concern is to ensure the safety of its employees.
There's a matter of some concern that I have to discuss with you.

definitions.meaning: something that involves or affects you or is important to you
examples: What were the major concerns of the writers from this period?
I don't want to hear about it - it's no concern of mine!
"What's happening?" "That's none of/not any of your concern."

definitions.meaning: to be important
examples: The results of the election are of concern to us all.
Drug trafficking is a matter of considerable concern for the entire international community .
Continued fighting in the city is causing great concern.
The recent drop in magazine subscriptions is causing some concern.
There is concern that the giant panda will soon become extinct.
There is general concern about rising crime rates.

definitions.meaning: to make small changes to something, especially in an attempt to repair or improve it
examples: He spends every weekend tinkering (around) with his car.
I wish the government would stop tinkering with the health service.

definitions.meaning: to grow, develop, or be successful
examples: His business thrived in the years before the war.
She seems to thrive on stress.

definitions.meaning: to develop in a particular way or in a successful way
examples: We'll have to see how things pan out.
Their attempt to start a new business didn't pan out.

definitions.meaning: to add more details or information to something
examples: These plans need to be fleshed out with some more figures.

definitions.meaning: a feeling of nervousness before an important or difficult event
examples: You could feel the tension in the room as we waited for our exam results.

definitions.meaning: a feeling of fear or anger between two groups of people who do not trust each other
examples: ethnic/racial tension
There are growing tensions between the two countries.

definitions.meaning: The tension of a wire or rope is the degree to which it is stretched.

examples: The tension in the office just dissolves when she walks out.
After the arrival of the United Nations soldiers, tension in the area began to ease.
His speeches fanned the flames of racial tension.
Many social workers are in the front line of racial tension.
The strong police presence only heightened the tension among the crowd.

definitions.meaning: If something is obligatory, you must do it because of a rule or law, etc.
examples: The medical examination before you start work is obligatory.
The statute made it obligatory for all healthy males between 14 and 60 to work.

definitions.meaning: expected because it usually happens
examples: Several Secret Service agents surrounded the President, all wearing the obligatory raincoat and hat.

definitions.meaning: familiar with something
examples: She quickly became accustomed to his messy ways.
I'm not accustomed to being treated like this.

definitions.meaning: usual
examples: She performed the task with her accustomed ease.

definitions.meaning: completely and finally:
examples: We have to decide, once and for all, whether we want to ask Dad for money.

definitions.meaning: to work hard and in a determined way, especially at something that you find difficult
examples: Katie has been plugging away at her homework for hours.

definitions.meaning: a glass or plastic container used in chemistry
a cup, usually with no handles, used for drinking
examples: She gave the children beakers of juice.

definitions.meaning: a pattern of different colored straight lines crossing each other at 90° angles, or a cloth with this pattern
to become larger and rounder than usual; to (cause to) increase in size or amount
examples: It was obvious she had broken her toe, because it immediately started to swell (up).
The group recruited more members, swelling its ranks (= increasing its size) to more than 1.3 million.
His heart/breast swelled with pride (= he felt very proud) as he stood watching his son graduate.

definitions.meaning: If music swells, it becomes louder.

examples: My foot swelled up to three times the normal size when it was stung by a wasp.
Excessive moisture will cause the wood to swell.
Tourists swell the local population during the summer months.
My arm swelled up where I was stung by a bee.
The banks of the river were swollen with the increased rainfall.

definitions.meaning: the outer, often curved or circular, edge of something
examples: The rim of the cup was chipped and broken.
My reading glasses have wire rims.

definitions.meaning: to be round or along the edge of something
examples: The martini glass was rimmed with sugar.

definitions.meaning: with a small piece or pieces broken off
examples: a chipped glass
All the plates were old and chipped.

definitions.meaning: very attractive, in a mysterious way, making you want to keep looking
examples: He had the most mesmerizing blue eyes.

definitions.meaning: unable to be explained or understood
examples: For some inexplicable reason, he's decided to cancel the project.

definitions.meaning: to learn how to do something, esp. when it is not simple or obvious:
examples: I’ll teach you how to use the design program – you’ll get the hang of it after a while.

definitions.meaning: continuing in a severe or extreme way
examples: relentless criticism/pressure
relentless heat

definitions.meaning: enthusiastic and eager
examples: a zealous supporter of the government's policies

definitions.meaning: to search, especially as if by digging, in order to find a thing or information
examples: She delved into her pocket to find some change.

definitions.meaning: to use something that already exists or has already been done successfully to do something else quickly or effectively
examples: The mobile phone company managed to break into European markets by piggybacking off existing networks.

definitions.meaning: to move a part of your body away from the rest of you
examples: She put out her hand to shake mine.

definitions.meaning: to injure a part of the body by pulling or twisting it
examples: I put my back out last week when I fell.

definitions.meaning: to stop something that is burning from continuing to burn
examples: Be sure to put out your campfire before you go to sleep.

definitions.meaning: to admit that you have done something wrong or something that you feel guilty or bad about
examples: She confessed to her husband that she had sold her wedding ring.
He confessed to sleeping/having slept through most of the movie.
He has confessed to the murder.
I have to confess (that) when I first met Reece I didn't think he was very bright.
It was all very confusing, I must confess.

definitions.meaning: in the Christian religion, especially the Roman Catholic Church, to tell God or a priest what you have done wrong so that you can be forgiven
examples: to confess your sins
I have to confess I'm a bit of a sucker for musicals.
I must confess that I got my sums wrong - the house extension is costing a lot more than I expected.
The killer confessed that he often drugged his victims before he killed them.
He was granted immunity from prosecution because he confessed the names of the other spies.
He confessed that he had sinful thoughts.

definitions.meaning: extremely violent, wild, or frightening
examples: a savage dog/beast
a brutal and savage attack

definitions.meaning: very serious or cruel
examples: savage criticism

definitions.meaning: very large and severe
examples: savage cuts in education spending

definitions.meaning: If an animal savages someone, it attacks them violently and causes serious injuries
examples: The child was savaged by a dog.

definitions.meaning: to suffer something difficult, unpleasant, or painful
examples: We had to endure a nine-hour delay at the airport.
She's already had to endure three painful operations on her leg.
During the war many couples had to endure long periods of separation .
The family said they had endured years of torment and abuse at the hands of the neighbours.
Words alone cannot convey the untold misery endured by people in these refugee camps.
By the third month of the expedition they had endured many hardships, but worse was to follow.
He endured his illness with great stoicism.

definitions.meaning: perfectly clean or tidy
examples: dressed in an immaculate white suit
an immaculate garden

definitions.meaning: perfect and without any mistakes
examples: He gave an immaculate performance as the aging hero.

definitions.meaning: to cause repeated suffering or anxiety
examples: Fighting in Vietnam was an experience that would haunt him for the rest of his life.
30 years after the fire he is still haunted by images of death and destruction.

definitions.meaning: (of a ghost) to appear in a place repeatedly
examples: A ghostly lady is said to haunt the stairway looking for her children.
Memories of the semifinal defeat haunted him for the rest of his career.
His experiences in the prison camp continued to haunt him.
She was haunted by memories of her unhappy childhood.
The novel tells the story of a soldier haunted by the events of the war.
The experience of failure continues to haunt him.

definitions.meaning: (of a person or a business) to be or become successful, especially financially
examples: Lots of microchip manufacturing companies prospered at that time.

definitions.meaning: a group of people who share a characteristic, usually age
examples: This study followed up a cohort of 386 patients aged 65+ for six months after their discharge home.

definitions.meaning: a group of people who support a particular person, usually a leader
examples: The Mayor and his cohorts have abused their positions of power.

definitions.meaning: to make someone or something extremely wet
examples: A sudden thunderstorm had drenched us to the skin.
The athletes were drenched in/with sweat.

definitions.meaning: impossible to change
examples: an irrevocable decision

definitions.meaning: to force someone or something to change direction
examples: I tried to head the dog off by running towards it.

definitions.meaning: to start a journey or leave a place
examples: What time are you heading off?

definitions.meaning: something that is very helpful and improves the quality of life
examples: Guide dogs are a great boon to the partially sighted.

definitions.meaning: very effective or surprising, or difficult to believe
examples: The diet promised miraculous weight loss.
Well, you've made a miraculous recovery since last night!

definitions.meaning: not proud or not believing that you are important
examples: He's very humble about his success.
Please accept our humble apologies for the error.
In my humble opinion (= I want to emphasize that I think that) we should never have bought the car in the first place.

definitions.meaning: poor or of a low social rank
examples: Even when she became rich and famous, she never forgot her humble background.

definitions.meaning: ordinary; not special or very important
examples: At that time she was just a humble mechanic.
Welcome to our humble abode (= our home).

definitions.meaning: to make someone understand that they are not as important or special as they thought
examples: He was humbled by the child's generosity.
The world champion was humbled (= unexpectedly defeated) by an unknown outsider in last night's race.

definitions.meaning: the actors in a film, play, or show
examples: After the final performance the director threw a party for the cast.
Part of the movie's success lies in the strength of the supporting cast (= the actors who were not playing the main parts).

definitions.meaning: an object made by pouring hot liquid into a container and leaving it to become solid
a plaster cast
If a part of your body is in a cast, it has a plaster cast around it to protect it while a broken bone repairs itself
examples: My leg was in a cast for about six weeks.

definitions.meaning: to send light or shadow (= an area of darkness) in a particular direction
examples: The moon cast a white light into the room.
The tree cast a shadow over/on his face.
Her arrival cast a shadow over/on the party (= made it less pleasant).

definitions.meaning: to provide an explanation for a situation or problem, or information that makes it easier to understand
examples: The discovery of the dinosaur skeleton has cast light on why they became extinct.

definitions.meaning: to look quickly at something
examples: Could you cast an eye over this report for me?

definitions.meaning: (in fishing) to throw something, such as a line, into the water to catch fish with
examples: He cast the line to the middle of the river.

definitions.meaning: to make an object by pouring hot liquid, such as melted metal, into a shaped container where it becomes hard
examples: If a part of your body is in a cast, it has a plaster cast around it to protect it while a broken bone repairs itself.

definitions.meaning: If a snake casts its skin, the outer layer of old skin comes off its body.
to become gradually damaged, worse, or less; to cause something to do this
examples: Sugar makes your teeth decay.
The role of the extended family has been decaying for some time.
Pollution has decayed the surface of the stonework on the front of the cathedral.
the smell of decaying meat

definitions.meaning: If a radioactive substance decays, it changes to a different form, producing radiation
examples: Radioactive uranium decays into stable lead at a known rate.
As the actinium-225 decays, it gives off short-lived, highly energized alpha particles.
Floating in the dirty river were dead fish, already starting to decay.
The bacteria live on food particles and produce acid that decays the enamel on your teeth.
The flesh on a dead body decays very rapidly.
It's sad to watch a beautiful rose wither and decay in such a short time.
Plants and animals decay into the soil, replenishing the minerals and nutrients.
Many children come to us with severe dental decay.
Unemployment and inner city decay are inseparable issues which must be tackled together.
Sugar is a major cause of tooth decay.
The mansion had an atmosphere of genteel elegance and decay.
Areas of the most serious urban decay are to receive funds for new building and redevelopment schemes.

definitions.meaning: to (cause something to) decay
examples: The fruit had been left to rot on the trees.
Rain has got in and rotted (away) the woodwork.
the smell of rotting fruit
Most of the crops had rotted in waterlogged fields.
Leave the leaves in a pile to rot.
Sugar rots your teeth.
The wood had rotted into dust.
Fruit had been left to rot in the fields.

definitions.meaning: decay
examples: Rot has got into the furniture.

definitions.meaning: not strong or clear; slight
examples: a faint sound/noise/smell
The lamp gave out a faint glow.
She gave me a faint smile of recognition.
There's not the faintest hope of ever finding him.
She bears a faint resemblance to my sister.
I have a faint suspicion that you may be right!

definitions.meaning: used to emphasize that you do not know something
examples: "Is she going to stay?" "I haven't the faintest idea."
I don't have the faintest idea what you're talking about!

definitions.meaning: to feel weak, as if you are about to become unconscious
examples: She felt faint with hunger.
The first faint signs of an agreement began to glimmer through.
She heard a faint, almost imperceptible cry.
They said the printing was too faint to reproduce well.
She felt a faint stirring of envy when she heard that one of her colleagues had been promoted.
A gap between the curtains admitted the faint glow of a street lamp.

definitions.meaning: to suddenly become unconscious for a short time, usually falling down
examples: He faints at the sight of blood.
I nearly fainted in the heat.
She took one look at the hypodermic needle and fainted (dead) away (= became unconscious immediately).
His face went pale and he looked as if he might faint.
You gave us a real scare when you fainted, you know.
He caught me at the precise moment that I fainted.
By the middle of the next day she was almost fainting from hunger.
I stood up too quickly and very nearly fainted.

definitions.meaning: especially in football and boxing, to pretend to move, or to make a move, in a particular direction in order to deceive an opponent
examples: Callas feinted to pass the ball and then shot it into the net.
He feinted a shot to the left.

definitions.meaning: to come close together in a group, or to hold your arms and legs close to your body, especially because of cold or fear
examples: Everyone huddled round the fire to keep warm.
It was so cold that we huddled together for warmth.
Sophie was so frightened by the noise of the fireworks that she huddled (up) in a corner of the room.

definitions.meaning: a small group of people or things that are close together
examples: A small group of people stood in a huddle at the bus stop.

definitions.meaning: to get into a group in order to talk secretly
examples: The judges went into a huddle to decide the winner.

definitions.meaning: to make sure that someone always knows what is happening
examples: Keep me posted on anything that happens while I'm away.

definitions.meaning: to obtain, buy, or earn something
examples: He went to the shop to get some milk.
I think she gets about £40,000 a year.
We stopped on the way to get some breakfast.
I managed to get all three suitcases for under $200.
How much did he get for his car? (= How much money did he sell it for?)
Where did you get your shoes from?

definitions.meaning: to receive or be given something
examples: I got quite a surprise when I saw her with short hair.
When did you get the news about Sam?
I got a phone call from Phil last night.
What grade did he get for the exam?
I got the impression that they'd rather be alone.
What did you get for your birthday?
We don't get much snow (= it does not often snow) here.
I managed to get a glimpse of him (= see him for a moment) through the crowds.
If you get a moment (= have time available), could you help me fill in that form?
She gets such pleasure from her garden.
If you can get some time off work, we could finish the decorating.
I can never get her to myself (= be alone with her) because she's always surrounded by people.

definitions.meaning: to go somewhere and bring back someone or something
examples: Let me go get my glasses.
Can I get you a drink?

definitions.meaning: to take someone or something into your possession by force
examples: Have the police got the man who did it yet?
Your cat got a bird this morning!

definitions.meaning: to reach or arrive at a particular place
examples: We hadn't even got as far as London when the car broke down.
What time does he normally get home (from work)?
If you get to the restaurant before us, just wait at the bar.

definitions.meaning: to reach a particular stage, condition, or time
examples: You earn loads of money if you get to the top in that profession.
It got to Thursday and she still hadn't heard any news.
I'm getting to the stage now where I just want to give up.

definitions.meaning: to make progress or to improve
examples: She's taking flute lessons, but she really doesn't seem to be getting anywhere with it.
It's been hard settling in, but I feel like I'm getting somewhere at last.

definitions.meaning: to become ill with a disease, virus, etc.
examples: I got food poisoning at that cheap little seafood restaurant.
Kids get all kinds of bugs at school.

definitions.meaning: to become or start to be
examples: He gets really upset if you mention his baldness.
Is your cold getting any better?
Your coffee's getting cold.
After a while you get used to all the noise.
You're getting to be such a big boy, aren't you!
How did you get to be a belly dancer?

definitions.meaning: to start to go or move
examples: We'd better get moving or we'll be late.

definitions.meaning: to cause something to happen, or cause someone or something to do something
examples: She had to get the kids ready for school.
I'm trying to get this article finished by Thursday.
We get our groceries delivered.
Were you able to get the copy machine working?
I can't get my computer to work!

definitions.meaning: to persuade someone to do something
examples: Why don't you get Nicole to come to the party?

definitions.meaning: to do something to something or someone without intending to or by accident
examples: He got his bag caught in the train doors as they were closing.
I always get the two youngest sisters' names confused.

definitions.meaning: sometimes used instead of "be" to form the passive
examples: I got shouted at by some idiot for walking past his house.
They're getting married later this year.
This window got broken.

definitions.meaning: to move to a different place or into a different position
examples: I hit my head as I was getting into the car.
Get out of here now or I'll call the police.
The bed is too wide - we'll never get it through the door.
Getting up the ladder was easy enough - it was coming down that was the problem.
He got down on his knees and asked me to marry him!

definitions.meaning: to travel somewhere in a train, bus, or other vehicle
examples: Shall we get a taxi to the station?

definitions.meaning: to deal with or answer a ringing phone, knock on the door, etc.
examples: Hey, Ty, someone's at the door - would you get it, please?

definitions.meaning: to have the chance to do something
examples: I never get to see her now that she works somewhere else.

definitions.meaning: to understand or hear something
examples: I didn't get what he said because the music was so loud.
I told that joke to Sophia, but she didn't get it.

definitions.meaning: to prepare a meal
examples: I'll put the kids to bed while you're getting dinner ready.

definitions.meaning: to pay for something
examples: Put your money away - I'll get these drinks.

definitions.meaning: to confuse someone and make them completely unable to understand or explain
examples: Give him a technical question - that'll really get him!

definitions.meaning: something that you say when you do not know the answer to a question
examples: "How many ounces in a kilo?" "You've got me there."

definitions.meaning: to annoy someone
examples: It really gets to me the way we're expected to actually laugh at his pathetic jokes!

definitions.meaning: to make someone feel strongly emotional and often cry
examples: That part in the film when he finds out that his daughter is alive - that always gets me!

definitions.meaning: to hit someone, especially with a bullet or something thrown
examples: The bullet got her in the leg.
The advantage of booking tickets in advance is that you get better seats.
What class of degree did you get?
I don't know if I can get the car tonight - I'll have to clear it with Mum.
She gets a 15% commission on every machine she sells.
I got some shoes cheap in the sale.
We enjoyed wonderful views when we got to the top of the mountain.
He was exhausted by the time he got to the finish line.
Your bags will be waiting for you when you get to the hotel.
The aid was getting to the people who needed it most.
She's been trying hard, but she doesn't feel that she's getting anywhere.
You can get very nasty skin diseases from bathing in dirty water.
I got a crick in my neck from painting the ceiling.
I can't come in to work today - I've got a bit of a dodgy stomach.
She's got a nasty dose of flu.
When I've got a cold, I don't feel like eating.
He got fed up with all the travelling he had to do.
The trouble with this carpet is that it gets dirty very easily.
Your essay gets a bit confused halfway through when you introduce too many ideas at once.
The music just gets distorted when you play it so loud.
It was getting dark now and we were tired.
These arguments always get my adrenalin going.
I've been running round in circles trying to get all the reports finished before the meeting.
Can you get this cork to come out of the bottle?
"Do you think you could get this parcel mailed for me, please?" "Consider it done."
The law has criminalized prostitution but not got rid of it.
He converted to Catholicism when he got married.
I got chucked out of the exam for cribbing from the guy in front.
My dress got all crushed in my suitcase.
For months I've been dining out on the story of what happened when my house got flooded.
Are you getting excited about your holiday?
Journalists had insisted on getting to the front line of the battle, heedless of the risks.
Security did not prevent an interloper from getting onto the stage at the opening ceremony.
You get into the building through a side door.
I tried to get in the cinema last night but it was full.
They got into the car and zoomed off.
It was a good job I got the earlier train.
You can get a bus from just outside the supermarket.
It'll be more expensive if you get a taxi.
It was too late to get a bus, so we had to walk home.
Get the train to King's Cross and I'll meet you at the station.
Pass me the bill. I'll get it.
Will you please get the phone?
That's the doorbell. You'd better get it.
If the phone rings when I'm in the shower, will you get it please?
If you get the drinks, I'll pay for the meal.
Did you get to visit your uncle when you were in Canada?
We never got to test drive the car before we bought it.
They got to play in the sandpit while the adults were shopping.
Who gets to have the last piece of chocolate cake?
We don't often get to spend the weekend together.
I didn't get that joke he told - did you?
Sorry, I still don't get it. You'll have to explain.
I didn't get that. Could you say it again?
I didn't get half of what he said because he talks so fast.
Did you get that? I hadn't a clue what he said.
I thought I could score some brownie points with my mother-in-law by offering to get dinner.
I'll do the main course, if you get the salad.
She was already up getting breakfast when I came downstairs.
I'll cook this evening, you got dinner last night.
He just sat in front of the TV while I was getting the dinner.

definitions.meaning: a feeling or opinion about something or someone, or a way of behaving that is caused by this
examples: It's often very difficult to change people's attitudes.
She takes the attitude that children should be allowed to learn at their own pace.
He has a very bad attitude to/towards work.
He seems to have undergone a change in/of attitude recently, and has become much more cooperative.
I don't like your attitude (= the way you are behaving).
That boy has a real attitude problem (= behaves in a way that makes it difficult for other people to have a relationship with him or work with him).

definitions.meaning: If you say that someone has attitude, you mean that they are very confident and want people to notice them.

examples: Her attitude has definitely changed for the better since she started this new job.
The bishop criticized the government for its "callous, uncaring attitude" to the homeless and the unemployed.
My relationship with my father played a major part in shaping my attitude towards men.
Middle age can be the prime of life if you have the right attitude.
He's often been accused of cynicism in his attitude towards politics.

definitions.meaning: to stick onto or hold something or someone tightly, or to refuse to stop holding it, him, or her
examples: We got so wet that our clothes clung to us.
They clung together in terror as the screams grew louder.
One little girl was clinging onto a cuddly toy.
She clung to the handrail as she walked down the slippery steps.

definitions.meaning: to stay close or near
examples: The road clings to (= closely follows) the coastline for several miles, then it turns inland.

definitions.meaning: to stay close to someone who is taking care of you, because you need their support
examples: Jenny is the kind of child who always clings whenever she's taken to a new place.
A few wisps of hay still clung to her skirt.
Kate was still clinging to the wreckage of her failed marriage.
She clung to my hand as we entered the doctor's surgery.
They discovered four men clinging to a piece of wood in the choppy seas.
Her wet hair clung to her face.

definitions.meaning: to have more money than you had in the past or more money than most other people
examples: Obviously we're better off now that we're both working.
When his parents died, he found himself $100,000 better off (= he had $100,000 more than before).

definitions.meaning: to be in a better situation, if or after something happens
examples: He'd be better off working for a bigger company.

definitions.meaning: people who have more money than most others
examples: The new tax will not have a serious impact on the better off.

definitions.meaning: to continue as planned
examples: His lawyers have decided not to proceed with the case.
Preparations for the festival are now proceeding smoothly.

definitions.meaning: to do something after you have done something else
examples: She sat down and proceeded to tell me about her skiing holiday.
He told me he was on a diet and then proceeded to eat a plateful of chips!

definitions.meaning: to move forward or travel in a particular direction
examples: Passengers for Madrid should proceed to gate 26 for boarding.
We need to think about how to proceed from here.
You should proceed with caution.
The suspect alighted from the train at Euston and proceeded to Heathrow.
He proceeded to relieve himself against a tree.
Should you decide to proceed with the treatment you will be contacted by the hospital.

definitions.meaning: the quality of being good and deserving praise
examples: an entertaining film with little artistic merit
Her ideas have merit.
Brierley's book has the merit of being both informative and readable.

definitions.meaning: the advantages something has compared to something else
examples: We discussed the merits of herbal tea.

definitions.meaning: according to the qualities you have or have shown, without considering any other information or comparing you to someone else
examples: The committee will consider/judge each applicant on his or her own merits.

definitions.meaning: If something merits a particular treatment, it deserves or is considered important enough to be treated in that way
examples: This plan merits careful attention.
The accident merited only a small paragraph in the local paper.

definitions.meaning: to move very fast, especially in a way that seems dangerous
examples: The truck came hurtling towards us.
The explosion sent pieces of metal and glass hurtling through the air.

definitions.meaning: to stop fighting and admit defeat
examples: They would rather die than surrender (to the invaders).

definitions.meaning: If you surrender to an experience or emotion, you stop trying to prevent or control it
examples: I finally surrendered to temptation, and ate the last piece of chocolate.

definitions.meaning: to give something that is yours to someone else because you have been forced to do so or because it is necessary to do so
examples: The police demanded that the gang surrender their weapons.
Neither side is willing to surrender any territory/any of their claims.
The rebels' ammunition is almost finished and it is only a matter of time before they surrender.
After their defeat in battle, the soldiers surrendered.
They laid down their weapons and surrendered.
The troops in front of us either surrendered or offered only token resistance.

definitions.meaning: something, such as a swimming pool or shopping centre, that is intended to make life more pleasant or comfortable for the people in a town, hotel, or other place
examples: The council has some spare cash, which it proposes to spend on public amenities.

definitions.meaning: things considered to be necessary to live comfortably, such as hot water
examples: The 200-year-old jail is overcrowded, understaffed, and lacking in basic amenities.

definitions.meaning: using something in a careless way and causing some of it to be wasted
examples: It's wasteful the way you throw so much food away!

definitions.meaning: to reduce or be reduced in size or importance
examples: I don't want to diminish her achievements, but she did have a lot of help.
These memories will not be diminished by time.
What he did has seriously diminished him in many people's eyes.
We've seen our house diminish greatly/sharply/substantially in value over the last six months.
Later on in life the sex drive tends to diminish.
Rising unemployment has diminished the bargaining power of people with jobs.
The inaccuracy of the missiles greatly diminishes their effectiveness.
Her popularity as a singer has diminished since the glory days of the 1980s.
Fresh snow meant that our chances of reaching the summit slowly diminished.

definitions.meaning: to keep or continue to have something
examples: She has lost her battle to retain control of the company.
He managed to retain his dignity throughout the performance.
She succeeded in retaining her lead in the second half of the race.
I have a good memory and am able to retain (= remember) facts easily.

definitions.meaning: If a substance retains something, such as heat or water, it continues to hold or contain it
examples: The sea retains the sun's warmth longer than the land.

definitions.meaning: to get the services of a lawyer by paying them before you need them

examples: He will retain the honorary title of non-executive chairman.
These plants need a rich soil which retains moisture.
When they divorced she retained a legal interest in the property.
The villagers retain a strong attachment to their traditional customs.
The management retains the right to refuse admission.

definitions.meaning: calm, serious, and controlled behaviour that makes people respect you
examples: He is a man of dignity and calm determination.
She has a quiet dignity about her.
I think everyone should be able to die with dignity.

definitions.meaning: the importance and value that a person has, that makes other people respect them or makes them respect themselves
examples: How could you wear something so indecent? Have you no dignity?
In hospital, she felt stripped of all her dignity.
He longs for a society in which the dignity of all people is recognized.
He regarded the comments as an affront to his dignity.
She comported herself with great dignity at her husband's funeral.
I accepted his decision that he wished to die with dignity.
He managed to retain his dignity throughout the performance.
He felt what he was being asked to do took away his dignity and self-respect.

definitions.meaning: to affect other people's opinion of someone or something, especially in a bad way
examples: When one player behaves disgracefully, it reflects (badly) on the whole team.
The whole affair does not reflect well on the government.

definitions.meaning: containing too many words
examples: As usual she gave a reply which was wordy and didn't answer the question.

definitions.meaning: to remove something by washing, or to disappear after washing
examples: I hope this stain will wash out.

definitions.meaning: (esp. of bad or violent weather) to cause something to fail, stop, or be destroyed
examples: Rain washed tonight’s game out.
The storm washed out roads and bridges.

definitions.meaning: to leave a mark on something that is difficult to remove
examples: Tomato sauce stains terribly - it's really difficult to get it out of clothes.
While she was changing the wheel on her car, her coat had become stained with oil.

definitions.meaning: If a material stains, it absorbs substances easily, causing it to become covered with marks, or coloured by a chemical
examples: This carpet is ideal for the kitchen because it doesn't stain easily.

definitions.meaning: to permanently spoil something such as someone's reputation
examples: Several important politicians have had their reputations stained by this scandal.
The country's history is stained with the blood of (= the country is guilty of killing) millions of innocent men and women.
Water and other liquids can stain unprotected wood surfaces.
Lily pollen stains really badly.
Red wine stains.
The wood itself was light but I stained it darker.
You can stain wood in different colours.

definitions.meaning: a dirty mark on something that is difficult to remove
examples: a blood/grass stain
You can remove a red wine stain from a carpet by sprinkling salt over it.

definitions.meaning: permanent damage to someone's reputation or character
examples: His solicitor said, "He leaves this court without a stain on his character."

definitions.meaning: present or noticeable in every part of a thing or place
examples: The influence of Freud is pervasive in her books.
a pervasive smell of diesel
Reforms are being undermined by the all-pervasive corruption in the country.

definitions.meaning: to make someone less confident, less powerful, or less likely to succeed, or to make something weaker, often gradually
examples: The president has accused two cabinet members of working secretly to undermine his position/him.
Criticism just undermines their confidence.
A succession of scandals and revelations has undermined the government over the past year.
Suddenly she just turned on me and accused me of undermining her.
The country's economic position has been seriously undermined by this affair.
He's been trying to undermine her position by spreading rumours about her.
If you continually criticize children you can seriously undermine their confidence.

definitions.meaning: to show something or to say or prove that something is true
examples: Thousands of people came out onto the streets to attest their support for the democratic opposition party.
The number of old German cars still on the road attests (to) the excellence of their manufacture.
As his career attests, he is a world-class tennis player.
The will needs to be attested (= officially marked to show that the signature of the person who made the will is correct) by three witnesses.

definitions.meaning: a long, thin stick of wood or metal, often used standing straight up in the ground to support things
examples: a telegraph/electricity pole
A flag fluttered from a 40-foot pole.
This totem pole is carved from a single tree trunk.
These poles will be easier to carry if we lash them together with a rope.
I gave the poles a slight wobble and the whole tent collapsed.
The vine twines round the pole.
The children of the village dance around a pole decorated with coloured ribbons.

definitions.meaning: a shelter for cars with a roof and one or more open sides that can be built against the side of a house
a cloth or plastic cover fastened to a building or structure and supported by a frame that is used to protect someone or something from the sun or rain
examples: The gaily striped awnings of the market stalls made an attractive scene.

definitions.meaning: a cover on a container, that can be lifted up or removed
examples: Can you get the lid off this jar?
Put a lid on the saucepan.

definitions.meaning: an eyelid (= either of the two pieces of skin that can close over each eye)
examples: She looked at him from under half-closed lids.
The lid of the coffin had been nailed down.
I can't get the lid off this jar.
Screw the lid on tightly.
I prized the lid off with a spoon.
She had used a screwdriver to puncture two holes in the lid of a paint tin.

definitions.meaning: easily deceived or tricked, and too willing to believe everything that other people say
examples: There are any number of miracle cures on the market for people gullible enough to buy them.

definitions.meaning: an idea that is based on feeling and for which there is no proof
examples: I had a hunch that you'd be here.
Sometimes you have to be prepared to act on/follow a hunch.

definitions.meaning: to lean forward with your shoulders raised or to bend your back and shoulders into a rounded shape
examples: We hunched round the fire to keep warm.
Stand up straight and don't hunch your back.

definitions.meaning: frightening and violent
examples: a ferocious dog
a ferocious battle
She's got a ferocious (= very bad) temper.
The president came in for some ferocious criticism.

definitions.meaning: When children play up, they behave badly
examples: The boys have been playing up at school again.

definitions.meaning: If a machine plays up, it does not work as it should
examples: The starter motor was playing up again.

definitions.meaning: the feeling of not liking someone or something and thinking that they do not deserve your interest or respect
examples: He regards the political process with disdain.

definitions.meaning: to feel disdain for someone or something
examples: The older musicians disdain the new, rock-influenced music.

definitions.meaning: to refuse to do something because you feel you are too important to do it
polite behaviour, or a polite action or remark
examples: You might get along better with your parents if you showed them some courtesy.
He could at least have had the courtesy to say sorry.
The president welcomed her visitors with the usual courtesies.
He replied sharply, and without his wonted courtesy.
At least do him the courtesy of listening to what he has to say.
He did have the courtesy to thank her for her efforts.
Always hold the door for the person behind you - it's just common courtesy.
She treated them with the greatest courtesy.

definitions.meaning: to start or continue doing something, especially more quickly or with more energy after a pause
examples: The meeting needs to finish by 5, so we'd better crack on.
Now we've prepared the walls we can crack on with the painting.

definitions.meaning: to use something for the wrong purpose in a way that is harmful or morally wrong
examples: She is continually abusing her position/authority by getting other people to do things for her.
I never expected that he would abuse the trust I placed in him.
to abuse alcohol

definitions.meaning: to treat someone cruelly or violently
examples: Several of the children had been sexually/physically/emotionally abused.

definitions.meaning: to speak to someone rudely or cruelly
examples: The crowd started abusing him after he failed to save a goal.
If you abuse your body now, you'll pay the price when you're older.
The Mayor and his cohorts have abused their positions of power.
In a landmark case/decision, the Governor pardoned a woman convicted of killing her husband, who had physically abused her.
People who have been abused as children often experience feelings/a sense of worthlessness.
The minister was sacked for abusing power for his personal gain.

definitions.meaning: the use of something in a way that is harmful or morally wrong
examples: an abuse (= wrong use) of privilege/power/someone's kindness
Drug and alcohol abuse (= using these substances in a bad way) contributed to his early death.

definitions.meaning: cruel, violent, or unfair treatment of someone
examples: She claimed to have been a victim of child abuse .
sexual/physical/mental abuse (= bad treatment)

definitions.meaning: rude and offensive words said to another person
examples: He had apparently experienced a lot of verbal abuse from his co-workers.
He hurled (a stream/torrent of) abuse at her (= he said a lot of rude and offensive things to her).
"Idiot!" is a term of abuse (= an insulting expression).
The government say they are trying to do more to educate the public about the consequences of drug abuse.
After years of abuse from her husband, she eventually found the courage to leave him.
Judge Hawthorne was chosen to head the team investigating the allegations of abuse.
There are few crimes more truly shocking than the murder or abuse of children.
The family said they had endured years of torment and abuse at the hands of the neighbours.

definitions.meaning: to move away from the main subject you are writing or talking about and to write or talk about something else
examples: But I digress. To get back to what I was saying, this poem reflects the poet's love of nature and his religious beliefs.
The lecturer temporarily digressed from her subject to deal with a related theory.

definitions.meaning: to try very hard to achieve something:
examples: Some people go to great lengths to make their homes attractive.
He'll go to any lengths to get what he wants.
